proof:
Let's start by considering any arbitrary configuration $F$ from the set $B_1$. From our analysis in Case 0 of the proof for Lemma 53, we recall that the count of single-vertex components in the graph $(V_C, F)$ does not exceed $(1 - \frac{2\eta}{3})n$. We will define $S$ as the set of all vertices belonging to components of size two or more.
It is important to observe that all edges within the configuration $F$ must connect vertices that are in $S$, which means the number of edges $|F|$ is bounded by the number of edges within the subgraph induced by $S$, denoted $e_G(S)$. By synthesizing the results from Lemmas 29, 30, and 35, we find that for a sufficiently large $d$, it is highly probable that any connected subset $S' \subseteq S$ will satisfy the inequality $e_G(S') \le |S'|(1+\max(1, d\eta/3))$. This leads to the conclusion that $e_G(S) \le |S|(2+d\eta/3)$. Given that $e_G(S)$ is at least as large as $|F|$, which in turn is at least $\frac{9\eta}{10}|E_C|$, it must follow that the size of $S$ is bounded below: $|S| \ge \frac{9\eta|E_C|}{10d(\eta/3+2/d)}$. Because every component that contributes to the set $S$ contains a minimum of two vertices, the total number of components in the configuration, $c(F)$, can be bounded above by $n - |S| + |S|/2$, which simplifies to $n - |S|/2$. With this, we can now establish an upper bound on the ratio of weights:
$$ \frac{w_G(F)}{w_G(\emptyset)} = q^{n-\frac{|S|}{2} - n_C}(e^\beta-1)^{|F|} \le q^{n - \frac{9\eta|E_C|}{20d(\eta/3+2/d)} - n_C} (e^{\beta_1}-1)^{\eta|E_C|} $$
The final inequality in this expression is a result of the condition $\beta \le \beta_1$ and the high-probability event that $n_C \ge n(1-e^{-d/3})$. For any sufficiently large $d$, the expression $\frac{9}{2(\eta/3+2/d)}-21$ will be greater than 1. Lemma 39 tells us that, with high probability, $|E_C|$ is at least $\frac{dn}{3}$. This allows us to conclude that the ratio $\frac{w_C(F)}{Z_C^{\text{dis}}}$ is less than $q^{-n[\eta/20-e^{-d/3}]}$. For a sufficiently large $d$, this upper bound can be simplified to at most $q^{-n\eta/30}$. Finally, by summing over all possible configurations $F$, of which there are at most $2^{|E_C|} \le 2^{dn}$, we arrive at the final result: $\pi_C^{\text{dis}}(B_1) \le e^{-n}$ for any sufficiently large $q$.
